name: Unholy hurricane of death (C 13 / M 2 / BG 25) - 10 attks +dev crits + buffs/s.attks + summons up to 1k+ dmg / round!!!!
author: Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi again!

Introduction:
I'm Orion and I'm back for another episode of NWN character building / experimenting, and can I say how much fun this has been.

Right now I am fascinated by builds that are able to 'do as much damage as possible', and as you know I created a Paladin/WM/Monk build last week which I thought did as much damage as could be possible in the game with a modest setup (300 mixed damage / round without crits, 450 damage / round with crits) and I thought definitely this could not be beaten in terms of damage output / round. Like I mean the character has 10 attacks + further buffed by holy might/eagle splendor/aura of glory, divine favor, bull strength and on top of that weapon master criticals.

Well I thought wrong!!! 

I am pleased to say I have found a build which does enough even more damage. And this time, NO Weapon Master (phew, the feat progression is so painful)! 

And to top it off, I found a way to incorporate the Devastating Critical Feat into the build. This means because of your 10 attacks / round, your opponent will on average, have to make at least one (possibly multiple!!!!) DC 41 Fortitude Save or Die, every round you attack them

Did I mention you get Level 7 Cleric Spells on top of it?

Is this overpowered or what? 

You will however, have to take a ride on the dark side to do so. Because it involves utilizing the Blackguard class. Welcome to the Unholy Hurricane of Death!!! I sincerely hope this entertains! By the way thanks so much for the feedback with my last post, it was very enjoyable to read. 

This time lets put a picture up of our brooding dark and lawful evil protagonist who definitely looks like he wants to kill some things (custom, from AdreannaDrea's male portrait pack on Steam) alongside his faithful and uncharacteristically cute and innocent looking demonic chaotic evil Epic Vrock companion before we get down to the details. 


The build:
Aims to do a lot of damage. Through:
- 10 attacks from double kamas / improved two weapon fighting / monk, flurry of blows and haste
- 3-4 attacks / round from your Epic Vrock companion (ie 14 attacks / round)
- Attacks on main hero and minion further buffed with lots of damage per hit. from
      + Cleric buffs (Divine Might, Divine Favor, Darkfire, Greater Magic Weapon, War Domain, Bull Strength)
      + Blackguard buffs (up to 9d6 sneak attack, Bull strength)
- Sneak attack frequency enhanced by
     + Blackguard Epic Vrock summon drawing aggression from enemies, knockdown
     + Up to Level 7 Cleric Spells such as sanctuary, invisibility, heal, word of of faith (AOE stun)
- Improved Critical and Devastating critical +10 attacks / round means your enemies will on average, have to make one DC 41 Fortitude save or die, every single round

There is some defensive capability as well from Cleric spells (including Improved Invisibility) and Blackguard Dark Blessing, Monk Wisdom AC which is also great to help you stay in fights as long as possible.

Downsides? 
- He's evil. 
- Lots of buffing means you might be vulnerable to dispel magic abilities
- No big fireballs to cast
- the build is M.A.D meaning Multiple Attribute Dependent (which is why cleric is good here, for the buffs)
- some micromanagement is recommend to try to maximise the number of sneak attacks possible, especially since I haven't included Knockdown in this build (I prioritized Blind Fight)
- low cleric caster levels is a pain if you want to stun someone with your spells to set up the sneak attacks
- somewhat low HP with CONS 8, only partially offset by cleric spells, and I found it hard to get the Toughness Feat with all the other feats I had to get to Devastating Critical + Lvl 7 Cleric Spells

Detailed damage / round calculations using buffs and equipment described:
Total Damage output / round:
Main Character:
8 attacks of 1d6 + 11 +1d4 acid + 4 slashing + 4 magic + 5 divine 1d6+6 fire (Crit 19-20/x2 +1d6 overwhelming critical +devastating critical chance of death) +9d6 sneak if relevant
2 attacks of 1d6 + 5 +1d4 acid +4 slashing +4 magic +5 divine 1d6+6 fire (Crit 19-20/x2 +1d6 overwhelming critical +devastating critical chance of death) +9d6 sneak if relevant

Plus Minion: 
Likely 3 attacks of 1-8 +8 +1d6+6fire (Crit 20/x2)
1 attack of 1-6 +8 +1d6+6fire (Crit 20/x2)

Total damage / round without criticals or sneak attacks : 
Main character
10d6+138 slashing 10d4 acid 40 magical 50 divine 10d6+60 fire = 
318 - 448 damage / round without criticals or sneak attacks for main character

Minion: 3d8+1d6+32 Physical + 4d6+24 Fire = 
64 - 110 damage / round without criticals for minion

Main character and minion:
382 - 558 damage / round for main character and minion without criticals or sneak attacks

With sneak attacks (+90d6):
472 - 1098 damage / round for main character with sneak attack, minion but no criticals

With criticals but no sneak attacks:

Criticals  (main 19-20/20x2 [110% damage] +1d6 1 in 10 attacks (overwhelming criticals) +fort save or death 1 in 10 attacks (devastating critical), minion 20x2=105% damage, sneak attacks not included in critical calculation, overwhelming critical added after critical modifier)

418 - 614.3 damage / round for main character and minion with criticals, overwhelming criticals but without sneak attack

plus one DC 41 Fortitude Save or death for opponent / round on average (could be more or less)

With sneak attack and criticals:

508 - 1154.3 / round for main character, minion with critical, overwhelming criticals and sneak attack

plus one DC 41 Fortitude Save or death for opponent / round on average (could be more or less)

So without sneak attacks you do approximately 500 damage / round, and if you have sneak attacks you do about approximately 830 damage / round!

Plus your opponent has to, on average, make a DC 41 fortitude save or die. This could be multiple if you are lucky with critical!!!

Of course this means your minion has to be behaving perfectly but your minion does about 80 damage / round which is pretty minimal considering the amount of damage you are doing.
 



Further comment - you could do even more damage:

1.    I haven’t used the War Domain buff (+3 damage / attack / round plus further bonuses)
2.    I haven’t used Aura of Vitality buff (+4 Str / Cons / Dex)
3.    I haven’t used Battletide spell (+2 damage / attack / saves)

So I could add a further 7 damage / hit, 77 damage / round (including critical) if I cast all those spells plus other bonuses.

But the downside of casting them is its short duration and it is annoying to have to recast them all the time so I haven’t used them in the calculation. But there may be situations before very tough fights you do cast these so it is relevant to mention.
 
Gameplay notes:
This build has multiple invisibility spells. Against an opponent who is susceptible to sneak attacks this pretty much guarantees 10 sneak attacks on the first round you break invisibility. In addition, you can recast this spell, reposition and attack / kill again.

You also have a minion who can draw aggression. You can also retreat from battle with your Tumble ability avoiding attacks of opportunity / use the sanctuary spell, to allow you to get another round of 10 sneak attacks in.

You have the greater invisibility spell, which provides 50% concealment, which is brilliant defensively against everything.

You could swap the War Domain with Magic Domain. You would exchange Cat's Grace and Aura of Vitality + War domain Buff, for Mage Armor and Stone Skin spells for slightly better defensive abilities. I think the War Domain is better though.

Finally:
Hope you enjoyed this post! Comments welcome as always. I still can't believe this game is 17 years old and I'm finding new things about it. 

And thanks to you guys for keeping the interest in NWN 1 alive, its been a blast so far.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I've taken this build through Aielund Saga Act 3 and Act 4 pt 1, 2 and 3. I thought I'd just make some general gameplay comments. I went from lvl 15 to lvl 36 in these 4 modules.

Aielund is somewhat biased against evil characters (for example, one companion will refuse to join you) but it is still fun especially when talking to Nelise who will tolerate almost anything you do with only very rare exceptions. Having so many companions available to you is great combined with your sneak attack ability. You will want a fighter in your party to draw agro and knock down enemies for you, and anything else on top of that is a bonus. There are also no unique kama weapons (the best I could find was a Kama +7) which is a contrast to the nwn campaign which had 4 unique kamas to choose from.

This build is best played in combat very rogueish, except you are using magic stealth rather than hide and move silently skills. Magic invisibility is probably superior to hide and move silently skills as you can 'hide in plain sight' without having to take a level in shadowdancer prestige class. It is also a total mage or cleric hunter and with invisibility/improved invisibility you can run past mobs to the backlines, cast your divine favour/divine might buffs, cast your fiend or other summon as a distraction, then break invisibility by attack with 3-5 knockdown attempts on that mage, to take out that mage before they can cast anything. If they are vulnerable to sneak attack they are usually dead unless they are some super major boss. Then you can keep using sneak attack on remaining enemies until you draw agro, run away, cast invisibility, rinse and repeat. I pretty much used this strategy all game until the end part where I will try to avoid saying any spoilers except pretty much at the end game every monster is immune to knockdown and has true sight which is really painful 

You can also save low health teammates by asking them to stop attacking, cast invisibility on them then heal them up with your heal skill (or spell, if you have lvl 6 cleric spells).

If you run out of invisibility then just stand next to your fighter and minion and play like a rogue even though you can take them on head to head, you are way more efficient if you can use your sneak attacks. Your minion will have a knockdown ability and haste which is pretty swell for you. 

Concentration is valuable to cast invisibility, divine favor, battletide and divine power buffs in the middle of battle, and those few levels of tumble at lvl 2 from monk +whatever dex bonus you have is actually sufficient to avoid about 50%-75% of attacks of opportunity which is great

Bull's strength, divine favor, battletide, divine power are great to boost your attack rating up so you can land those 10 sneak attacks more often on those difficult to hit bosses and enemies. It's a real pain to watch you throw out 10 hits, and only 2 of them hit, so if you encounter this, back off and cast those buffs and go back in. It's particularly an issue because greater magic weapon is nerfed in Aielund to the extend it is pretty much worthless. Darkfire is useful but also not as strong as in the normal game and the game will not let you cast it on certain weapons that are too strong..

Because your caster level is reasonably lowish (ie cleric 9-13 against lvl 30 monsters), you are very vulnerable to dispel magic abilities. It's always best to get your fighter/paladin to draw attention and the dispel magic then engage. This might mean casting your summon / divine favor / divine might / other buffs while invisible and this is happening.

Damage resistant enemies are a pain. Constructs ie golems and the undead are a pain as they are immune to criticals, sneak attack and usually will have reduced damage modifiers. Adding weapon damage to your primary weapon, particularly acid damage, will make Aielund so much easier. Divine might and divine favor (the mod changed the damage type to divine rather than magical) will also help as usually divine damage will bypass these modifiers.

You can manage your CONS 8 stat which is a pain, by careful re-rolling, endurance spell and some items. I was running around with 400-450 hp by the end of the game, with my fighter having 550, which isnt too bad.

You can also ignore devastating critical as they disabled that feat in the modules, and put the feat points from those abilities into other things such as greater strength, toughness improved knockdown etc.

I will try to minimise spoilers but there is a part of the game where you will need to fight without access to kamas, and your fists are actually more than sufficient when you do 7 attacks with with DM, DF, Bull Strength etc

Anyway, thought I'd just share my experience. Invisible blackguard sneaking around with 10 sneak attacks + other buffs is pretty lethal and I just felt like I was a total assassin with amazing combat abilities buffs heals and summons and saves

posts.content: When I play a Monk in Aielund, I always go unarmed, rather than dual kamas.  There are good gloves to be had, especially the gloves you can get from a certain dragon in the shadow realm.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote: When I play a Monk in Aielund, I always go unarmed, rather than dual kamas.  There are good gloves to be had, especially the gloves you can get from a certain dragon in the shadow realm.
Thanks for your comment. I hadn't seen the gloves until your post, and I've loaded up a save game, and they are pretty nice! 

The gloves you reference have +10 AB and 2d12 magic damage which gives an unarmed weapon damage range of 3-18 with two levels of monk (with my build), but 3-32 as a primary class monk (at least lvl 16)

The best Kama I could get was an Kama +7 1d6, which i then enchanted with Keen and +2d10 acid which gives you a weapon damage range of 10 to 33 and then other buffs to increase it further

You can't cast Darkfire on your fists which is 1d4-1d6 fire damage depending on your cleric level, so you can get a damage range of 11-39 with a darkfire enchanted Kama

So as a primary monk given the 2d12 magic damage type will bypass a lot of damage reduction, it could be slightly better but if you can enchant the kama appropriately it is still not bad, in fact still quite comparable

As a secondary monk it looks like you can get a bit of damage out of an appropriately enchanted kama and you free up a glove slot for something else

 if you want to go unarmed or single kama with this build you can ditch TWF, Ambidexterity, ITWF for other feats and lower your dex and increase other stats such as strength, cons or charisma. you'd still get 8 attacks with flurry and haste, which will hit more often given you are not dual wielding. I just have a weakness for 10 attacks LUL

small edit: the weapon enchantment was +2d10 , not +1d10

posts.content: Hey Orion, I really like your concept. I just planned another evil SoU + HotU playthrough and I have a question: how would you change your build to level 28? would you just end up at level 28 with the division: cleric 11 / monk 1 / blackguard 16?

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
kaillan wrote: Hey Orion, I really like your concept. I just planned another evil SoU + HotU playthrough and I have a question: how would you change your build to level 28? would you just end up at level 28 with the division: cleric 11 / monk 1 / blackguard 16?
Thanks for your message Kailan. I actually hadn't thought about this in detail even when I was going through HoTU.

Your schedule is ok, it gives you access to the level 6 heal spell which is great to keep your companions alive.

I feel I've gotten better at building since I wrote my initial post having getting feedback from the experienced hands on the forum.

Having played through HoTU I would probably go Cleric 15 Monk 3 Blackguard 10. 6 levels of Blackguard beyond 10 give 2d6 sneak attack epic vrock and one bonus feat. 4 cleric levels and 2 monk level gives you level 7 and 8 spells (Mass Heal! :), a stronger Divine Favor buff and a further tumble dump for +5AC. You could continue pumping blackguard after that. In epic levels your BAB increases the same whether you raise Cleric Monk or Blackguard. If you go Cleric 8 Monk 2 BG 10 pre-epic you get one extra AB compared with Cleric 9 M 1 BG 10.

Level 15 is nice for cleric as you maximize Greater Magic Weapon and Divine Favor. Thats 10AB for two spells, if you have mundane equipment. Its great if you do 10 sneak attacks, but even better if all of them hit!!!!

There is a vendor who will enchant your weapons for a lot of gold. If you need to prioritise, obviously prioritise your main weapon which will do 6-8 attacks / round (depending if you are flurried and/or hasted) rather than your offhand which will only do 2 attacks per round regardless of flurry or haste

If you are a total power gamer, there is also a secret location where you can enchant up to two weapons with the ability to damage your enemy's strength statistic per hit which is crazy strong with this build. Just be sure to maximise your weapon with the above vendor before you take these enchantments because he will refuse to further enchant your weapon as it is already 'too powerful' :)

Feats I would remove with a level 28 limitation would be the greater cleave and improved critical (kama) feats, because you aren't going to get near devastating critical and take other feats. Improved critical (Kama) will only increase your total damage output by 5%.

Getting extra wis is not wasted as you get extra AC from Monk class and a better Will save

You could probably delay your third level of Monk if you plan to take this character through, say Aielund, where Cleric 15 Monk 3 BG 22 would be perfectly fine. But if you are limited to 28 levels, one extra monk level gives you more than one black guard level (ie BG 10-11 gives far less than M2-3)

posts.content: Thanks for the quick response. I wonder if it would not be better idea to build a character around Divine power - drop strength to 8 and pump wisdom - you will get 18 str, fighter's level BAB, more AC and spells per day. For example at level 10 cleric you would have at least 8x Divine power. What do you think?

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
kaillan wrote: Thanks for the quick response. I wonder if it would not be better idea to build a character around Divine power - drop strength to 8 and pump wisdom - you will get 18 str, fighter's level BAB, more AC and spells per day. For example at level 10 cleric you would have at least 8x Divine power. What do you think?
If you want to build it around divine power with Str 8 with a level cap of 28, with a wisdom focus, in the way you describe, it is probably best to go primary cleric with one or two epic levels of monk for the 6-10 attacks per round (depending if you want ITWF) and monk wisdom AC. The weakness of DP in a minor class cleric is the short duration. Throughout my playthrough I rarely used Divine Power simply because 9-13 rounds is not long before you need to recast the ability with only 9-13 levels of cleric.  I also didn't take the extend spell feat. You already are casting DF and DM regularly and if you have 10 attacks per round, you want to be hitting as much as possible, not spending most of that time casting buffs. Its obviously different if you have 37 levels of cleric and extend spell. Theres quite a few Cleric / Monk builds on the ECB database (http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... index.html) if you want to go down this path. Don't get me wrong, primary cleric is superstrong

I would also probably ditch Blackguard if you focus on DP and take Str 8. This is because you will miss out on one of the strengths of a Cleric / BG combo which is stackable Bull's Strength which provides up to 10 strength. There is a +12 stat cap you will reach with Divine Power very easily, even without items or the stackable Bull's Strength. You will also not have enough strength for Power attack (and hence Divine Might). Without Divine Might you may be tempted to 'dump' charisma as well as strength, which would lead to a negative value to saves from Dark Blessing. (unlike Divine Grace, Dark Blessing can make your saves worse with a negative Charisma modifier). If you want some sneak attacks (who wouldn't if you do 10 attacks!) 1 level of rogue is nice for a further tumble dump, UMD? If you want to go all in on Sneak and just use cleric for buffs, you could check out Mick Dagger's (up to 10 attack build with DP) Cleric / Monk / Assassin build around Divine Power (http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... 64737.html) although level 8 cleric is not a great number to stop leveling cleric, because level 9 cleric gives you Divine Favor +3 rather than +2, I think Mick was trying to fit in as much Assassin power as possible + 10 APR into the build.
